person:biography.personal-details:content:
Magdalena Pastuch, PhD in linguistics, professor at the Department of Lexicology and Semantics in the Institute of Polish Language at the University of Silesia.
I graduated from the University of Silesia in Katowice, Poland. I obtained my PhD degree in 1996 – the title of dissertation was “Semantic and Structural Changes in Polish Denominal Verbs”. Since 1985 I have been working at the Institute of Polish Language. In 2008 I published a monography “Hidden Heritage. Traces of Old Lexicon in the Lexsis of Contemporary Polish” and I got the habiliation. I am especially interested in the history of language and its numerous trends – starting from historical word formation to semantics and historical pragmatics. I conduct research on changes in words’ meaning and variability of notions. The most intriguing phenomena for me are lexicalization and grammaticalization, which refer to both the language system and language use. I deal with universal language phenomena, but I observe them in the Polish language. The second important research direction is glottodidactics. I am the author a lot of article about teaching Polish as a foreign language and co-author of the manual for the beginners.

keyword:keyword.keyword:content: Historical Semantics, Historical Pragmatics, Word Formation
